frontmatter.title: Build System
frontmatter.description: Understanding the Documentation Engine build system and hot reload

children.value:
title: Build System
description: Understanding the Documentation Engine build system and hot reload
path: /build-system
order: 6
- You are viewing the latest documentation.
Documentation Engine uses a build-time optimization strategy where markdown files are pre-parsed for fast loading. This page explains how the build system works and how to use it effectively.
The build system has two main components:
- Converts markdown to JSON at build time
Large bundle size (~500KB+ for markdown parser)
Slow initial page load (parsing on every visit)
Small bundle size (~50KB for core runtime)
You don't need to run it when:

# Parse markdown files manually
npm run build:parser

# Start development server (includes hot reload)
npm run dev

# Build for production (includes build:parser automatically)
npm run build

# Preview production build
npm run preview
, a custom Vite plugin watches the
folder and automatically rebuilds when you edit markdown files:

# 2. Edit markdown files

frontmatter.title: Home
frontmatter.description: Welcome to the Documentation Engine - A powerful plugin-driven documentation system

children.value:
title: Home
description: Welcome to the Documentation Engine - A powerful plugin-driven documentation system
path: /
order: 1
- You are viewing the latest documentation.

Documentation Engine is a modern, plugin-driven documentation system built on Skeleton Crew Runtime. Transform your markdown files into beautiful, interactive documentation websites with powerful features out of the box.
Documentation Engine showcases the power of Skeleton Crew's plugin architecture, demonstrating how complex applications can be built using simple, composable plugins.
- Write content in markdown with embedded React components
- Fast, client-side search powered by MiniSearch
- Live code editors with real-time preview
- Works perfectly on mobile, tablet, and desktop
- Export to static HTML for fast hosting

# Install dependencies
npm install skeleton-crew-runtime unified remark react react-dom

# Create your first markdown file
echo "# Hello World" > docs/index.md

# Initialize the runtime
npm run dev
Here's a simple markdown file with frontmatter:

---
title: My Page
description: A simple documentation page
path: /my-page
order: 1
---

# My Page

Welcome to my documentation!

## Code Example

```javascript
console.log('Hello, Documentation Engine!');
```
Documentation Engine supports MDX components for rich, interactive content:
This is a live callout component! You can use these to highlight important information in your documentation.

title: Skeleton Crew Runtime
description: Learn what, why and how Skeleton Crew Runtime is the foundation of the docs engine
path: /skeleton-crew-runtime
order: 5
üß≠ Advanced Use Case: Building a Documentation Website Using Skeleton Crew

Skeleton Crew is not just a plugin-driven internal tool builder ‚Äî it is a flexible, declarative runtime capable of powering full websites. One powerful example is using Skeleton Crew to build and deploy a
This document shows how, why, and when Skeleton Crew can serve as a
, what plugins are needed, how the dev workflow looks, and how it compares to traditional static site generators.
What Makes Skeleton Crew Suitable for Docs?
‚úîÔ∏è Deployability to a static host or server
This makes it ideal for a highly customizable, plugin-driven documentation engine.
2. What Makes Skeleton Crew Suitable for Docs?
Skeleton Crew plugins can define documentation features:
: Markdown parser, MDX compiler, syntax highlighter
: CodeBlock, Tabs, Callout boxes, Live Playground
: Search indexer, theme switcher, version selector
The event bus enables plugins to react to changes:
Since Skeleton Crew has no built-in routing, a
This demonstrates Skeleton Crew's philosophy: even core features like routing are plugin-driven.

# Getting Started

Welcome to **Skeleton Crew Docs**.

## Installation

```bash
npm install @skeleton/runtime
```

## Quick Example

Here's a minimal plugin:

```typescript
export const myPlugin = {
  name: "my-plugin",
  setup(context) {
    context.screens.registerScreen({
      id: "home",
      title: "Home",
      component: HomeScreen
    });
  }
};
```

## Interactive Demo

<Playground>
  <Button variant="primary">Click me</Button>
</Playground>

<Callout type="info">
  Plugins can contribute screens, actions, and event handlers.
</Callout>

* [Explore the API](/api/runtime)
* [See examples](/examples/todo-app)

Skeleton Crew documentation sites support multiple deployment strategies:
Most documentation sites, GitHub Pages, Netlify, Vercel
crawls all registered screens and pre-renders them to HTML:

# 1. Initialize runtime
# 2. Load all plugins
# 3. Markdown plugin registers all pages
# 4. Execute static export action
npm run build

# Output:
# dist/
#   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.html

# Deploy to Netlify
netlify deploy --dir=dist

# Deploy to GitHub Pages
gh-pages -d dist

# Deploy to Vercel
vercel --prod

Internal docs, rapid iteration, dynamic content

# Bundle runtime + plugins

npx serve dist
No rebuild for content changes (just update .md files)
Large docs sites, optimal SEO, dynamic content
A Node.js server runs the Skeleton Crew runtime and renders pages on-demand:

# Deploy to Node.js host
npm run build:ssr
node dist/server.js

# Or use serverless
vercel deploy  # Vercel Functions
netlify deploy # Netlify Functions
Include runtime bundle for client-side interactivity
Hydrate on client for dynamic features (search, theme toggle)

# Getting Started

Welcome to **Skeleton Crew Docs**.

## Installation

```bash
npm install @skeleton/runtime
```

## Quick Example

Here's a minimal plugin:

```typescript
export const myPlugin = {
  name: "my-plugin",
  setup(context) {
    context.screens.registerScreen({
      id: "home",
      title: "Home",
      component: HomeScreen
    });
  }
};
```

## Interactive Demo

<Playground>
  <Button variant="primary">Click me</Button>
</Playground>

<Callout type="info">
  Plugins can contribute screens, actions, and event handlers.
</Callout>

## Next Steps

* [Learn about plugins](/guides/plugins)
* [Explore the API](/api/runtime)
* [See examples](/examples/todo-app)

1. Markdown Plugin parses file
   ‚Üì
2. Extracts frontmatter: { title, description, path, order }
   ‚Üì
3. Identifies MDX components: <Playground>, <Callout>
   ‚Üì
4. Resolves components from Component Registry
   ‚Üì
5. Registers screen with metadata
   ‚Üì
6. Router Plugin creates route: /getting-started ‚Üí screen
   ‚Üì
7. Sidebar Plugin adds to navigation tree
   ‚Üì
8. Search Plugin indexes content
   ‚Üì
9. React UI Plugin renders when user navigates

# 1. Initialize runtime
# 2. Load all plugins
# 3. Markdown plugin registers all pages
# 4. Execute static export action
npm run build

# Output:
# dist/
#   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.html
#   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ getting-started.html
#   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ guides/
#   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ plugins.html
#   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ assets/

# Deploy to Netlify
netlify deploy --dir=dist

# Deploy to GitHub Pages
gh-pages -d dist

# Deploy to Vercel
vercel --prod

# Bundle runtime + plugins
npm run build:spa

# Output:
# dist/
#   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.html          # Single HTML file
#   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ bundle.js           # Runtime + plugins
#   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ docs/               # Raw markdown files
#       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ getting-started.md
#       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ guides/

# Any static file host
npm run build:spa
npx serve dist

# Deploy to Node.js host
npm run build:ssr
node dist/server.js

# Or use serverless
vercel deploy  # Vercel Functions
netlify deploy # Netlify Functions

Install Skeleton Crew Runtime via npm:
Create a simple application with a single screen:
The Runtime must be initialized before use:

await runtime.initialize();
Plugins must be registered before initialization:
Screens are registered within plugin setup:
Version 1.0 provides the foundation for building plugin-driven applications.

You are viewing documentation for version 1.0.
Plugins are the primary way to extend Skeleton Crew functionality.
A basic plugin has this structure:
: Plugin is registered with the runtime
: Plugin interacts with the runtime via context
The context provides access to runtime subsystems:
Here's a complete example of a counter plugin:
: Choose clear plugin and action names
: Wrap action handlers in try-catch blocks
: Let other plugins know about state changes
: Each plugin should have a single responsibility
In v1.0, plugins cannot be unregistered after initialization.

You are viewing documentation for version 1.0.
Skeleton Crew is a minimal, plugin-based application runtime for building internal tools and modular applications.
The Runtime is the main orchestrator that initializes and coordinates all subsystems.
Plugins extend the runtime with custom functionality. Each plugin can:
Screens represent different views or pages in your application.
Actions are executable operations that can be triggered by user interactions or other plugins.
Ready to build your first application? Check out our
to learn about available methods and interfaces.
